000: There are no laws or regulations defining post-disaster recovery institutions, no review of planning instruments after disasters, and no guidelines for damage and needs assessments. Resilient reconstruction capacity is very limited.
001: Guidelines for post-disaster assessments exist, but institutions are undefined and planning instruments have not been reviewed. Assessment tools exist, but governance and practical application are weak.
010: Planning instruments have been reviewed after disasters, but no legal framework or assessment guidelines exist. Some practical reconstruction steps are taken, yet institutional anchoring and systematic assessment are missing.
011: Planning instruments are reviewed and assessment guidelines exist, but institutions are not defined. Reconstruction shows operational measures and assessment capacity, but lacks formal governance.
100: Institutions for coordinating post-disaster recovery are defined by law or regulation, but planning instruments have not been reviewed and assessment guidelines are missing. Governance exists, but operational and analytical capacity is limited.
101: Institutions are defined and assessment guidelines exist, but planning instruments have not been reviewed. Governance and assessment capacity are in place, yet practical reconstruction improvements are incomplete.
110: Institutions are defined and planning instruments have been reviewed, but guidelines for assessments are missing. Governance and operational review are strong, but systematic assessment is lacking.
111: Post-disaster recovery institutions are legally defined, planning instruments have been reviewed, and guidelines for damage and needs assessments are in place. Resilient reconstruction in {country} is well-coordinated, systematic, and guided by both governance and technical standards.
